column1: Gniezno ([ˈɡɲeznɔ] (listen); German: Gnesen) is a city in central-western Poland
column2: about 50 kilometres (31 miles) east of Poznań
column4: 943 inhabitants making it the sixth-largest city in the Greater Poland Voivodeship. One of the Piast dynasty's chief cities
column5: it was the first historical capital of Poland in the 10th century and early 11th century
column8: as the capital of Piast Poland. The Roman Catholic archbishop of Gniezno is the primate of Poland
column9: making it the country's ecclesiastical capital. It has belonged since 1999 to the Greater Poland Voivodeship
column10: and is the administrative seat of Gniezno County (powiat).

column1: There are archaeological traces of human settlement since the late Paleolithic. Early Slavonic settlements on Lech Hill and Maiden Hill are dated to the 8th century. At the beginning of the 10th century this was the site of several places sacred to the Slavic religion. The ducal stronghold was founded just before AD 940 on Lech Hill
column2: and surrounded by some fortified suburbs and open settlements.

column1: According to the Polish version of a legend
column2: three brothers went hunting together but each of them followed a different prey and eventually they all traveled in different directions. Rus went to the east
column3: Čech headed to the west to settle on the Říp Mountain rising up from the Bohemian hilly countryside
column6: he followed his arrow and suddenly found himself face-to-face with a fierce
column7: white eagle guarding its nest from intruders. Seeing the eagle against the red of the setting sun
column8: Lech took this as a good omen and decided to settle there. He named his settlement Gniezno (Polish gniazdo – 'nest') in commemoration and adopted the White Eagle as his coat-of-arms. The white eagle remains a symbol of Poland to this day
column9: and the colors of the eagle and the setting sun are depicted in Poland's coat of arms
column11: with a white stripe on top for the eagle
column12: and a red stripe on the bottom for the sunset. According to Wielkopolska Chronicle (13th century)
column14: a Pannonian prince. He had three sons – Lech (the oldest)

column2: being an important pagan cult center
column3: became one of the main fortresses of the early Piast rulers
column4: along with aforementioned fortresses at Giecz
column12: and others. Archeological excavations on Lech Hill in 2010 discovered an 11th-century tomb by the foundations of St. George's church
column13: near the remains of a pagan burial mound discovered earlier on the hill. Discoveries indicate that Lech Hill could have been the burial place of rulers even before the baptism of Mieszko I of Poland. After the adoption of Christianity by Mieszko I
column14: his son Bolesław I Chrobry deposited the remains of Saint Adalbert in a church
column16: to underline Gniezno's importance as the religious centre and capital of his kingdom.

column1: It is here that the Congress of Gniezno took place in the year 1000 AD
column2: during which Bolesław I the Brave
column4: received Holy Roman Emperor Otto III. The emperor and the Polish duke celebrated the foundation of the Polish ecclesiastical province (archbishopric) in Gniezno
column5: along with newly established bishoprics in Kołobrzeg for Pomerania; Wrocław for Silesia; Kraków for Lesser Poland in addition to the bishopric in Poznań for western Greater Poland

column1: The 10th-century Gniezno Cathedral witnessed the royal coronations of Bolesław I in 1024 and his son Mieszko II Lambert in 1025. The cities of Gniezno and nearby Poznań were captured
column2: plundered and destroyed in 1038 by the Bohemian duke Bretislav I
column3: which pushed the next Polish rulers to move the Polish capital to Kraków. The archepiscopal cathedral was reconstructed by the next ruler
column5: who was crowned king here in 1076.

column1: In the next centuries Gniezno evolved as a regional seat of the eastern part of Greater Poland
column2: and in 1238 municipal autonomy was granted by the duke Władysław Odonic. Gniezno was again the coronation site in 1295 and 1300.

column3: became a county seat within the Kalisz Voivodeship (since the early 14th century till 1768). It was destroyed again by the Teutonic Knights' invasion in 1331. The city was soon rebuilt during the reign of King Casimir III the Great
column4: while during the reign of King Władysław II Jagiełło
column6: the status of "the capital of Christianity in Poland" was confirmed after the archbishops of Gniezno were given the title of Primate of Poland. Trade flourished in Gniezno
column7: four large annual fairs took place
column8: in which merchants from various Polish cities and European countries took part. Crafts also developed
column9: and Gniezno remained one of the major cities of Poland until the mid-17th century
column10: even despite fires of 1515 and 1613. It was devastated during the Swedish invasion wars of the 17th–18th centuries and by a plague in 1708–1710. All this caused depopulation and economic decline
column11: but the city was soon revived during the 18th century to become the capital of the Gniezno Voivodeship within the larger Greater Poland Province of the Polish Crown in 1768. Gniezno remained one of the main cultural centeres of the Polish Kingdom.

column1: Gniezno was annexed by the Kingdom of Prussia in the 1793 Second Partition of Poland and renamed Gnesen
column2: becoming part of the province of South Prussia. During the Kościuszko Uprising
column3: the Polish army under General Jan Henryk Dąbrowski liberated the town on 22 August 1794 and defeated a Prussian Army north of Gnesen near Labischin (Łabiszyn) on 29 September 1794. But because of Kościuszko's defeat at the Battle of Maciejowice he gave up his plan to winter in Bromberg (Bydgoszcz) and moved through Thorn (Toruń) and retreated to central Poland. Thus
column4: the Prussians retook it on 7 December 1794. During the Napoleonic Wars there was an uprising against Prussian rule. The French appeared in Gnesen in November 1806
column5: and following General Jan Henryk Dabrowski's order issued to all towns and cities and country property owners to provide recruits for the organizing Polish forces
column6: Gnesen initially provided 60 recruits who participated in the battles of 1806–07. Consequently
column7: the town was included within the Duchy of Warsaw
column8: but upon the defeat of Napoleon in Russia in 1812 it was occupied by the Russian army and was returned to Prussia in the 1815 Congress of Vienna. Gnesen was subsequently governed within Kreis Gnesen of the Grand Duchy of Posen and the later Province of Posen. It was an important center of Polish resistance against Germanisation policies
column9: various Polish organizations and publishing houses were located there.Following the Greater Poland Uprising (1918–1919) and the Treaty of Versailles the town became part of the Second Polish Republic and reverted to its original name of Gniezno. Its citizen-soldiers joined the Polish army fighting the Bolsheviks during the Polish–Soviet War.

column3: Gniezno was captured by Germans troops on 11 September 1939. On 26 October 1939 it was annexed into Nazi Germany as part of Reichsgau Wartheland. During the German occupation
column4: local Poles were subjected to arrests
column5: expulsions and mass executions. The Germans murdered several hundred inhabitants
column7: 000 inhabitants of the city and county were expelled to the General Government or imprisoned in Nazi concentration camps. In late 1940 at the Dziekanka (Tiegenhof in German) psychiatric institute near Gniezno
column8: 1172 patients were evacuated and then killed. Again in late 1940 hundreds of patients were gassed in gas van by the Lange Commando
column9: a sub-unit of Einsatzkommando 2. Despite this
column10: Gniezno remained a center of Polish resistance.After the city was seized by the Red Army on January 21
column12: the Soviets fought the Polish underground and deported its members deep into the Soviet Union. The city itself was not seriously damaged during the war
column15: the Germans demolished the monument of King Bolesław I the Brave
column16: which was rebuilt after the war. The city was subsequently restored to post-war Poland.

column2: Pope John Paul II visited Gniezno. During the second visit
column3: celebrations took place on the millennial anniversary of the death of St. Adalbert with the participation of presidents of seven Central European countries and 280
column4: 000 pilgrims from Poland and the world. In 2000
column5: the millennial anniversary of the Congress of Gniezno was celebrated and on this occasion the Sejm was held in Gniezno
column6: the only one held outside of Warsaw in recent decades.

column1: Gniezno's Roman Catholic archbishop is traditionally the Primate of Poland (Prymas Polski). After the partitions of Poland the see was often combined with others
column2: first with Poznań and then with Warsaw. In 1992 Pope John Paul II reorganized the Polish hierarchy and the city once again had a separate bishop. Cardinal Józef Glemp
column3: who had been archbishop of Gniezno and Warsaw and retained Warsaw
column4: was designated to remain Primate until his retirement
column5: but afterward the Archbishop of Gniezno
column7: would again be Primate of Poland.

column1: 25 December 1025 – Mieszko II Lambert and his wife Richensa of Lotharingia

column2: one of the historically most important Polish churches

The city's most popular sports club is motorcycle speedway team Start Gniezno. The annual speedway Bolesław Chrobry Tournament is held in Gniezno. The city's main football club is Mieszko Gniezno.
